abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Power
            Engineering and Technical Assistance Project for Guinea was
            unsatisfactory. The project achieved its objectives, its
            impact on institutional development was modest,
            sustainability is uncertain, and the performance of the Bank
            was satisfactory while the Borrower's was
            unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, granting greater management responsibility
            in exchange for a performance-based approach to technical
            assistance could have offered better prospects. Second, in
            the future, GOG should only agree to measures which are
            within its capacity to execute and the Bank should be more
            circumspect in accepting such assurances at face value.
            Finally, IDA played a crucial role in bringing about
            fundamental sector reforms. Its support was a critical
            element that finally resulted in a turn around situation,
            which may not have otherwise been achieved.
